case_name: Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd. v. Corporation of Calcutta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 8 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 8 of 1963. V. Viswanatha Sastri and D.N. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: On or about October 2, 1879, the Corporation of the town of Calcutta entered into an agreement with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfresh Parrish and Robinson Souttar granting right to construct, maintain and use certain tramways in Calcutta on payment of rents.

anchor.surface_text: On or about October 2, 1879, the Corporation of the town of Calcutta incorporated under Bengal Act IV of 1876 entered into an agreement in writing with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfrest Parrish and Robinson Souttar, hereinafter called the grantees whereunder the Corporation granted to the said grantees the right to companystruct, maintain and use certain tramways in Calcutta on payment of certain rents as provided in the said agreement

facts.text: The 1879 agreement contained an arbitration clause for referring disputes arising under the agreement to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement companytained an arbitration clause which provided for referring any disputes arising under the said agreement to arbitration in the manner prescribed thereunder.

facts.text: Clause 28 of the 1879 agreement provided that the words 'the said Corporation' would include the Corporation and its successors.

anchor.surface_text: The said agreement further provided in cl. 28 that the words the said Corporation would include the Corporation and its successors.

facts.text: Different agreements entered into on November 22, 1879, September 2, 1893 and December 9, 1899 between successors of Corporation and grantees, confirmed by Acts.

anchor.surface_text: Different agreements were entered into between the successors of the Corporation of Calcutta and the grantees from time to time, namely, on November 22, 1879, September 2, 1893 and December 9, 1899, and were companyfirmed by appropriate Acts.

facts.text: All agreements contained arbitration clause similar to the first agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In all these agreements the appellants predecessor-in-interest agreed to pay the rents to the respondents predecessors-in-interest in respect of the tramways companystructed, maintained and used by them.

facts.text: Corporation of Calcutta is the successor of the properties of the Corporation of the town of Calcutta constituted under Bengal Act IV of 1876, constituted by Bengal Act II of 1888.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Calcutta is number the successor of the properties of the Corporation of the town of Calcutta companystituted under the Bengal Act IV of 1876. It was companystituted by Bengal Act II of 1888.

facts.text: Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd. (appellant) is the successor or assignee of the grantees.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, i.e., the Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd., is the successor or the assignee of the said grantees.

facts.text: On August 30, 1951, State of West Bengal entered into agreement with appellant to purchase the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1951, the State of West Bengal entered into an agreement with the appellant whereby the Government agreed to purchase the undertaking of the appellant as provided in the said agreement.

facts.text: Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951 (W.B. Act XXV of 1951) was passed and came into effect on October 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951  W.B. Act XXV of 1951  was passed and it came into effect on October 18, 1951.

facts.text: Under the Act, Government of West Bengal was substituted for the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements, subject to reservation that sums payable under agreements shall be payable by appellant to the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Act the Government of West Bengal was practically substituted for the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements subject to a reservation that any sums payable under the said agreements shall be payable by the appellant to the Corporation

facts.text: Disputes arose as regards the track rent payable by the appellant to the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose as regards the track rent payable by the appellant to the Corporation and the dispute was referred to arbitration

facts.text: The dispute was referred to arbitration in accordance with the terms of the arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: and the dispute was referred to arbitration in accordance with the terms of the arbitration clause. Though the parties appointed arbitrators in terms of the arbitration clause of the agreements,

facts.text: Parties appointed arbitrators in terms of the arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: Though the parties appointed arbitrators in terms of the arbitration clause of the agreements, the appellant numberinated its arbitrator without prejudice to its rights

facts.text: Appellant filed application on January 7, 1963, in Original Side of Calcutta High Court for determination whether valid arbitration agreement existed.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant numberinated its arbitrator without prejudice to its rights and filed on January 7, 1963, an application in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, inter alia, for the determination of the question whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (A.N. Ray, J.) held there was a valid arbitration agreement between appellant and respondent, appellant was party to arbitration clauses, respondent could make reference to arbitration, and reference was valid.

anchor.surface_text: The application was heared by A.N. Ray, J. who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses companytained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent companyld make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective.

facts.text: Appellant filed present appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, by special leave, has filed the present appeal against the said order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant contended that all rights of Corporation under agreements transferred to Government under Tramways Act, 1951 except sums payable, so Corporation cannot rely on arbitration clauses.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Shastri, learned companynsel for the appellant, companytended that all the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation and that, therefore, the Corporation companyld number rely on the arbitration clauses

facts.text: The agreement of August 30, 1951 between Governor of West Bengal and Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd. was confirmed by West Bengal Act XXV of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Act the agreement entered into on August 30, 1951, between the Governor of West Bengal on the one part and the Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd. on the other part was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act confirmed the transfer agreement and made it binding.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act says, The transfer agreement is hereby companyfirmed and made binding on the parties thereto and the several provisions thereof shall have effect as if the same had been enacted in this Act.

facts.text: Section 4 transferred powers and duties of various bodies re tramways to Government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 enacts that numberwithstanding anything to the companytrary in any other law, all the powers and duties of the Corporation of Calcutta. the Commissioners of the Howrah Municipality,

facts.text: Section 5 provided agreements in Second Schedule have effect as if Government were parties in lieu of bodies in column 2, with proviso that sums payable continue payable as if Act not passed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5, which is the crucial section, reads The several agreements particulars whereof are set out in the Second Schedule to this Act shall have effect as if the Government were parties thereto in lieu of the respective bodies and persons set out in companyumn 2 of the said Schedule and any reference in any such agreement to any of such bodies or persons shall unless the subject-matter or the companytext otherwise requires be deemed to be a reference to the Government Provided that any sums payable under any such agreement to any of such bodies or persons shall companytinue to be payable as if this Act had number been passed.

facts.text: Second Schedule contains list of titles of the various agreements.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Schedule companytains a list of the titles of the various agreements mentioned by us earlier.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that both the right to sums payable and arbitration procedure are saved under proviso to s.5.

anchor.surface_text: On such a companystruction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5, which is the crucial section, reads The several agreements particulars whereof are set out in the Second Schedule to this Act shall have effect as if the Government were parties thereto in lieu of the respective bodies and persons set out in column 2 of the said Schedule and any reference in any such agreement to any of such bodies or persons shall unless the subject-matter or the context otherwise requires be deemed to be a reference to the Government Provided that any sums payable under any such agreement to any of such bodies or persons shall continue to be payable as if this Act had not been passed.

issues.text: whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

anchor.surface_text: for the determination of the question whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

issues.text: whether the Corporation could rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable in terms of the said agreements to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Shastri, learned counsel for the appellant, contended that all the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation and that, therefore, the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses

arguments.claim: All the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation, therefore the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Shastri, learned counsel for the appellant, contended that all the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation and that, therefore, the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that, therefore, the Corporation companyld number rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the s

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso to s.5 saves both substantive right to sums payable and interconnected procedural right to arbitration; fiction excluded where context requires

arguments.claim: There was no valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

anchor.surface_text: for the determination of the question whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion that any sums payable under the said agreements shall be payable by the appellant to the Corporation Disputes arose as regards the track rent paya

arguments.court_reasoning: Lower court held valid; Supreme Court upheld by rejecting challenge

arguments.claim: There was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent; appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements; the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements; the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective

anchor.surface_text: The application was heard by A.N. Ray, J. who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective.

arguments.claim: Under s.5, Government substituted for Corporation unless subject-matter or context otherwise requires; proviso saves sums payable from fiction, agreements remain intact as if Act not passed, respondent continues as party for sums payable

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5 of the Act the Government is statutorily substituted for the respondent or its predecessors-in-interest in the various agreements stated supra. The fiction is a well defined one. The Government replaces the Corporation and its predecessors-in-interest as a party to the agreements unless the subject-matter or the context otherwise requires. The natural presumption is that but for the proviso the enacting part of the section would have included the subject-matter of the proviso also. The proviso to s. 5 saves from the operation of the substantive section the sums payable under any such agreements

arguments.claim: Relevant agreements provided for recovery of rents via arbitration clauses; without Act, Corporation could refer rent disputes to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: The relevant agreements provided for the recovery of the rents and also for the procedure for the recovery of the sums so payable in accordance with the terms of the arbitration clauses of the agreements. Had not the Act been passed and had the Government not been substituted in the place of the Corporation, it cannot be denied that the Corporation, if a dispute arose in regard to the rent, could have referred the dispute to arbitration.

arguments.claim: Substantive right to payment of rent and procedural right to arbitration are interconnected and not severable; preserving substantive right without procedural denies remedy

anchor.surface_text: The substantive right to the payment of rent and the procedural one to have any dispute arising in respect of that right referred to arbitration embodied in the agreements are interconnected and are not severable. To preserve the substantive right and to withhold the procedural right to enforce it is to save the right and to deny the remedy.

arguments.claim: Accepting appellant's contention makes new agreement, compels Corporation to give up agreed remedy

anchor.surface_text: To accept the contention of the appellant is to make out a new agreement between the parties in respect of the sums payable. The acceptance of this suggestion compels the Corporation to give up its agreed remedy.

arguments.claim: Alternative that Government enforces arbitration introduces incongruity as dispute is with Corporation but arbitration with third party; no trustee provision in Act

anchor.surface_text: The alternative suggestion, namely, that in respect of the amounts payable to the Corporation the arbitration clauses of the agreements could be enforced by the Government against the appellant introduces an incongruity. While the dispute would be between the appellant and the Corporation, the arbitration would be between the appellant and a third party. The argument that the Government would be acting as a trustee of the Corporation in respect of the sums payable to the Corporation is not supported by any of the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Proviso brings sums payable (substantive and procedural aspects) within scope of exception to fiction; fiction yields to contract terms

anchor.surface_text: Further, in the substantive part of s. 5 of the Act the fiction takes effect unless the subject-matter or the context otherwise requires. The proviso in terms as well as by necessary implication brings the subject-matter of the sums payable under the agreements both under the substantive and procedural aspects within the scope of the said exception. The fiction in s. 5 of the Act shall yield to that extent, to the terms of the contract. On such a construction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.

holdings.text: there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective

anchor.surface_text: The application was heared by A.N. Ray, J. who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court determination based on agreements containing arbitration clauses; Supreme Court upholds by rejecting appellant's challenge under the Act

holdings.text: both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved under the proviso to s.5 of the Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: On such a construction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.5 saves sums payable 'as if this Act had not been passed'; substantive right to payment and interconnected procedural arbitration remedy non-severable; substitution fiction yields where subject-matter or context requires; avoids anomalies and new implied contract

anchor.surface_text: On such a companystruction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.
